title: Health Economics Fundamentals through the Vermont Health Reform case and Act 167 v3
summary: This deep-dive analysis uses the 2024 Oliver Wyman Act 167 report as a living case study to illustrate the core principles of health economics defined in Bhattacharya's seminal textbook. We explore how theoretical concepts like the 'Volume-Outcome Relationship,' 'Baumol's Cost Disease,' and 'Asymmetric Information' explain the collapse of Vermont's rural hospital market.

body.title: Audio Deep Dive: Theory Meets Reality
body.summary: An extended discussion connecting Bhattacharya's 'Medical Arms Race' theory to the specific insolvency data of Vermont's 14 hospitals.

children.text: The discipline of Health Economics exists because health care violates the standard rules of market economics. In a normal market, supply and demand equilibrate prices. In Vermont, however, we see a 'market failure' where premiums have risen 108% in six years while hospital operating margins have plummeted. By overlaying the theoretical framework from Bhattacharya's
Health Economics
onto the empirical data from the Act 167 recommendations, we can diagnose the structural pathologies of the system.
1. Scarcity and the Production Possibility Frontier

The fundamental axiom of economics is scarcity. Vermont is currently operating beyond its Production Possibility Frontier (PPF). The Wyman report indicates that maintaining the status quo will require '$2.4BN total ($3.7K per capita)' in additional funding over five years just to break even. This represents a resource allocation problem: the state cannot sustain 14 full-service hospitals with a shrinking working-age population (-13% by 2040).

children.text: 2. Industrial Organization: The Volume-Outcome Relationship
Chapter 6 of the
Health Economics

textbook defines the 'Volume-Outcome Relationship' as the positive correlation between the number of procedures performed and patient outcomes due to 'learning by doing'. Vermont's fragmented system violates this principle.

“Surgeons and hospitals who perform the same procedure over and over again seem to have better post-operative results... The volume-outcome relationship for hospitals is greater in magnitude than for individual physicians.” — Bhattacharya, Chapter 6

The Wyman report confirms this theoretical risk: 'Low volume of procedures to sustain operational excellence' is cited as a primary operational challenge. Specifically, hospitals like North Country are performing femoral hernia repairs and small bowel resections at volumes so low they risk clinical quality. This justifies the recommendation for 'Regionalization of specialty care services,' effectively creating Centers of Excellence to restore the volume-outcome curve.

children.text: 3. The Physician Labor Market and Barriers to Entry

In Chapter 5, Bhattacharya explains that high physician wages are maintained by 'barriers to entry,' such as licensure and residency caps. While these ensure quality, they create supply shortages. Vermont is experiencing a severe 'Supply Shock.' The Wyman report notes 'Cumbersome licensure requirements' as a key driver of the shortage, forcing hospitals to hire expensive travel nurses and locum tenens physicians.

The economic solution proposed is substitution. Just as a factory might substitute capital for labor, the report recommends 'Expand professional licensure and practice scope for nurses, EMT and pharmacists'. This lowers the barrier to entry for providing routine care, shifting the supply curve outward to meet demand.
4. Information Economics and Moral Hazard
A key finding in the Wyman report is that 26-37% of Emergency Department visits across Vermont hospitals are 'avoidable'. In economic terms, this is a form of
Moral Hazard

: because patients are insured (or seeking 'last resort' care), they consume expensive ED resources for conditions that could be treated in cheaper settings. The recommendation to 'Expand access to primary care settings' aims to correct this allocative inefficiency.

children.text: POLICY: Reference-Based Pricing

To combat the market power of hospitals in oligopolistic rural markets (Chapter 6), the report suggests 'Reference-based pricing ideally at 200% of Medicare'. This acts as a price ceiling, preventing hospitals from using their monopoly power to shift costs onto commercial payers indefinitely.
